summary: This is an email chain from November 26, 2021, containing press guidance from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It clarifies that witnesses will testify under pseudonyms and provides logistical information for the media.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity. Her trial is the subject of the press guidance.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Ghislaine Maxwell conspired to commit the alleged crimes.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned in the context of the final pretrial conference.

persons.name: Jim Margolin
persons.context: A colleague in the SDNY press office who media can contact to establish an account for accessing government exhibits.

persons.name: Dipesh Gadher
persons.context: A reporter for The Sunday Times who is seeking clarification on whether he can identify a witness by name, given a previous waiver of anonymity.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity.

events.title: Press Guidance Issued for Maxwell Trial
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York issues press guidance regarding the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, instructing media on witness pseudonyms and trial logistics.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference
events.description: Scheduled final pretrial conference for U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell before Judge Alison Nathan.

locations: Courtroom 318, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY (Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse)
1 London Bridge Street, London SE1 9GF, UK (The Sunday Times office)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office confirms that several government witnesses in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial will testify using a pseudonym or first name, as ordered by the court.
The guidance states the witnesses are victim witnesses expected to describe 'illegal sexual abuse, sexual contact and other acts' and urges media to respect their privacy.
The document reveals a media inquiry about identifying a witness who had previously waived anonymity, highlighting the tension between press reporting and victim protection.
The trial involves charges that Ghislaine Maxwell conspired with Jeffrey Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity.
Logistical details for the trial are provided, including the use of a file share for exhibits and the need for media to establish PACER accounts.
